required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Acute Effects of Low-dose TNF-α on Glucose Metabolism and β-cell Function in Humans
clinical_study.official_title: The Acute Effects of Low-dose TNF-α on Glucose Metabolism and β-cell Function in Humans

collaborator.agency: Copenhagen Muscle Research Centre, Rigshospitalet, Copenhagen, Denmark

brief_summary.textblock:
Type 2 diabetes is characterized by increased insulin resistance and impaired insulin secretion. In addition, type 2 diabetes is associated with low grade inflammation indicated by increased levels of proinflammatory cytokines such as TNF-α. TNF-α has previously been shown to impair peripheral insulin signaling in vitro and in vivo. However, it is unclear whether TNF-α may also affect endogenous glucose production (EGP) during fasting and glucose stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS) in vivo.
We hypothesized that low dose TNF-α would increase EGP and attenuate GSIS. Recombinant human TNF-α or placebo was infused in healthy, non-obese and non-diabetic young men (n=10) during a 4-hour basal period followed by an intravenous glucose tolerance test (IVGTT).

primary_outcome.time_frame: Measurements at 0h, 1h, 2h, 3h and 4h during basal period. After glucose bolus infusion, measurements every 1 min for the first 30 min and every 3 mins for the next hour. Last measurement 1,5 hours post- IVGTT
primary_outcome.description: Insulin levels (pg/ml) in blood measured continually before and after Intravenous glucose tolerance test. Glucose bolus infused in healthy young men after a 4 hour basal period. Subsequent measurements og insulin and glucose levels in peripheral blood

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy men
- Age 20-35
Exclusion Criteria:
- obesity (BMI>25)
- diabetes
- chronic disease

facility.name: 1 The Centre of Inflammation and Metabolism, Department of Infectious Diseases and CMRC, Rigshospitalet, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Copenhagen

results_reference.citation: Plomgaard P, Fischer CP, Ibfelt T, Pedersen BK, van Hall G. Tumor necrosis factor-alpha modulates human in vivo lipolysis. J Clin Endocrinol Metab. 2008 Feb;93(2):543-9. Epub 2007 Nov 20.
